awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: Collaborative Research: F: RDMA-Based Datacenter Networks for Online Big Data Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses the challenge of achieving extreme low latency in datacenter networks for Online Big Data (OLBD) applications which are critical workloads in datacenter computing. Remote Direct Memory Access (RDMA), which is a promising alternative to traditional TCP, significantly reduces datacenter network latencies by about an order-of-magnitude. However, RDMA adoption poses two major challenges as RDMA suffers from performance fragility under congestion, and  RDMA incurs either wasted memory or significant programmer burden for typical OLBD traffic. This project develops two novel networking technologies -- Blitz and RIMA -- which enable scalable datacenter networks that achieve the low latency benefits of RDMA while avoiding its drawbacks (performance fragility, programmer burden, and wasted memory).

Blitz addresses performance fragility by decoupling edge-congestion and in-network congestion. Blitz handles edge-congestion using receiver-directed congestion control (RDCC) unlike prior approaches where senders have to infer sending rates indirectly from round-trip-times and/or dropped packets. RDCC enables accurate and fast (within-one-round-trip-time) convergence, which leads to lower latency and higher throughput. Blitz handles transient in-network congestion by deflecting packets along longer yet less-congested paths.
Remote Indirect Memory Access (RIMA)  addresses the second challenge by enabling reactive, on-demand memory allocation as opposed to RDMAs proactive memory allocation for the worst case, which minimizes the memory footprint without programmer effort. Together, Blitz and RIMA enable extreme low datacenter network latency for OLBD applications. The project will extensively involve Ph.D, Masters, and undergraduate students in cross-layer research activities. Results from the projects will be broadly disseminated via publication in scientific conferences.

por.por_cntn:
Big Data applications that respond to user queries (e.g., web search) require low latency from the datacenter network. Existing TCP stacks require OS intervention during each data transfer, which adds overhead to network transfers. Remote Direct Memory Access (RDMA) networking stacks (e.g., Infiniband, RoCE) eliminate OS intervention and promise network latencies that are shorter by one-to-two orders of magnitude as compared to TCP. Therefore, RDMA is being considered as a potential replacement to TCP in datacenters that host Big Data applications. The key outcomes of this project are the development of techniques to address the bottlenecks of existing RDMA implementations in order to realize the true potential of RDMA in datacenters. Specifically, this project has two major outcomes to address two major problems. 

First,  existing RDMA stacks do not perform well during congestion because they either do not provide end-to-end congestion control or their congestion control is too slow to react to sudden bursts. This project developed a novel design to address this challenge by achieving quick congestion control in the common case of receiver congestion. Measurements show that our design achieves substantial improvements in latency (e.g., 4.8x lower 99th percentile latency) and throughput (e.g., 58% higher throughput) than prior schemes. These findings have been disseminated broadly via a conference poster, a journal paper and a patent issued by the USPTO.

Second, existing RDMA stacks incur wasted memory or significant programmer burden for some common Bid Data traffic patterns which often have unpredictable bursts, widely varying message sizes and can involve an unpredictable number of communicating hosts. This project developed a novel approach -- Remote Indirect Memory Access (RIMA) -- which provides a robust communication primitive that seamlessly handles the variation/unpredictability of Big Data traffic without imposing memory overheads or programmer burden. Purdue researchers built a real testbed with 30 nodes and evaluated RIMA using synthetic and real applications which confirm the advantages of RIMA. These findings have been disseminated via a journal paper and a patent issued by USPTO (which has since been licensed by a major semiconductor company).

In addition to the above major outcomes, other outcomes include the development of Big-Data-focused architectures, networking layer optimizations and application layers optimizations targeted at improving Big Data applications.
